fields.title: Overexpression Targeted Knock-In
fields.content:
Technical Background

Using CRISPR-Cas9 for targeted knock-in at safe harbor sites involves:

  • Cas9: An endonuclease that creates a double-strand break (DSB) at the target site.
  • Guide RNA (gRNA): Directs Cas9 to the specific safe harbor locus.
  • Donor DNA template: A construct containing the desired transgene flanked by homology arms that are complementary to the sequences adjacent to the DSB, which facilitates targeted insertion via homology-directed repair (HDR).

Safe harbor sites are specific regions in the genome where foreign DNA can be inserted without disrupting vital endogenous gene functions or causing harmful effects to the cell. These sites are often utilized for stable gene insertion in genome engineering because they support long-term and predictable expression of transgenes.

Several common safe harbor loci include:

  • AAVS1 (PPP1R12C locus) on chromosome 19
  • ROSA26 locus in mice
  • H11 locus in human and murine genomes

Features of Our Products

  1. Our CRISPR and donor vectors are designed to be more streamlined, facilitating efficient target gene integration compared to commercially available products.
  2. Many products rely on non-targeting lentivirus for gene incorporation, leading to random integration, which poses safety risks and unforeseen complications, particularly in gene therapy and clinical research. Our vector and virus kits, however, deliver targeted integration at specific safe harbor sites, significantly mitigating these risks.
  3. Unlike market alternatives that require electroporation, which demands specialized equipment and techniques, our plasmid kits are user-friendly and suitable for most labs, making them ideal for adherent cancer cell lines. For hard-to-transfect cells, we also offer a hybrid solution that combines the large gene capacity of lentivirus with the reduced integration effects of AAV virus, providing a convenient, research-focused kit.

Experiments Involved in CRISPR Targeted Knock-In at Safe Harbor Sites

Regular Plasmid

  • gRNA Selection: The guide RNA is designed to specifically target the chosen safe harbor site. The sequence must be carefully chosen to maximize on-target specificity and minimize off-target activity.
  • Cas9 Delivery: The CRISPR-Cas9 system can be delivered into cells using various methods such as plasmids, mRNA, or RNP (ribonucleoprotein complexes). Delivery methods depend on the cell type and the specific requirements of the experiment.
  • The donor DNA contains the gene of interest (GOI) along with homology arms (typically 500-1000 bp) that match the sequence flanking the target safe harbor site.
  • Depending on the application, the donor template may include selection markers (e.g., antibiotic resistance genes or fluorescent reporters) to aid in the identification of successfully modified cells.

Stable Cell Line Construction

  • Cell Type: Common cell types used include HEK293, iPSCs, and other therapeutic or industrially relevant cell lines.
  • Transfection: Cells are co-transfected with the gRNA, Cas9, and donor template using transfection methods such as electroporation, lipofection, or viral vectors (e.g., lentivirus or AAV). These methods vary depending on the cell type and efficiency requirements.
  • Antibiotic Selection/Fluorescence Screening: If the donor contains a selection marker, antibiotic resistance or fluorescence-based sorting (e.g., FACS) can be used to enrich cells that have undergone successful knock-in.
  • PCR and Sequencing: PCR is used to amplify the regions flanking the insertion site, followed by sequencing to confirm that the gene of interest was correctly integrated into the safe harbor locus.
  • Validation of Transgene Expression and Function

Applications of CRISPR Knock-In at Safe Harbor Sites

Our techniques are expected to be used in different research area including gene therapy, reporter or controlled gene applications, various disease models, antibody production, and iPSC regeneration.

fields.title: Gene Deletion
fields.content:
Technical Background

CRISPR Genome Knockout Deletion is a powerful and versatile gene-editing technique that allows for the targeted removal or deletion of specific genomic sequences. This approach uses the CRISPR-Cas9 system, which is derived from the bacterial adaptive immune system and has been adapted for genome editing in a variety of organisms.

Key Components

  1. Cas9 Protein: A nuclease that introduces double-strand breaks (DSBs) at specified genomic locations based on the guidance of a complementary RNA sequence.
  2. Guide RNA (gRNA): A synthetic RNA molecule designed to bind to a specific target sequence in the genome, directing the Cas9 protein to the intended site.
  3. DNA Repair Mechanisms: Following the DSB created by Cas9, the cell's natural repair mechanisms take over. The primary repair pathways involved are:
    • Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ): This is the predominant pathway used for gene knockout. NHEJ can lead to insertions or deletions (indels) at the break site, causing frameshifts or premature stop codons, ultimately resulting in gene knockout.
    • Homology-Directed Repair (HDR): Although not typically employed for knockout deletions, HDR can be utilized for precise gene editing if a donor template is provided.

Feature of Our Products

  1. We designed a specialized structure for the simultaneous delivery of two gRNAs, enabling the efficient removal of target genomic fragments larger than 10 kb.
  2. Unlike market alternatives that require electroporation, which demand specialized equipment and techniques, our plasmid kits are user-friendly and suitable for most labs, making them ideal for adherent cancer cell lines. For hard-to-transfect cells, we also offer a hybrid solution that combines the large gene capacity of lentivirus with the reduced integration effects of AAV virus, providing a convenient, research-focused kit.

Experimental Process

  1. Designing gRNA or Donor Vectors:
    • A gRNA targeting the specific gene of interest is designed, typically targeting an exon or crucial regulatory region to ensure effective knockout.
    • Online tools can assist in selecting gRNA sequences that minimize off-target effects.
  2. Delivery of CRISPR Components:
    • The Cas9 protein and gRNA can be delivered into target cells using our kits, utilizing the corresponding transfection methods.
    • Plasmid Transfection: Introducing plasmid DNA encoding Cas9 and gRNA into cells.
    • Viral Vectors: Using lentiviruses or AAVs to deliver the editing components into hard-to-transfect cells.
  3. Screening and Validation:
    • PCR Amplification: Target regions are amplified using specific primers to check for the presence of indels.
    • Functional Assays: Evaluating the biological effects of the knockout through various assays (e.g., proliferation, apoptosis).
    • Western Blotting or qPCR: Techniques to confirm the absence of the target protein or reduction in mRNA levels.
    • Functional Characterization: Further studies to assess the impact of the knockout on cellular processes.

Applications for CRISPR Genome Knockout Deletion

This technique can be utilized to study the functions of non-coding regions of the genome, create disease models such as Huntington's disease, unravel the complexity of gene clusters, investigate chromatin architecture, and explore the role of pathogenic copy number variations (CNVs).

fields.title: Gene Knock-In Tagging
fields.content:
Technical Background

Gene knock-in tagging is a technique used to insert specific tags (such as fluorescent proteins, epitope tags, or functional domains) into precise locations in the genome, typically at the 3' or 5' ends of target genes. This allows for real-time tracking of gene expression, localization of proteins, or functional studies of gene products without disrupting the gene's natural regulatory mechanisms. The CRISPR-Cas9 system is the cornerstone of gene knock-in tagging. It employs a guide RNA (gRNA) to direct the Cas9 endonuclease to a specific genomic site, where it creates a double-strand break (DSB). The DSB is then repaired by either non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) or homology-directed repair (HDR). For knock-in tagging, HDR is typically used, where a donor template containing the tag and flanked by homology arms facilitates the precise insertion of the desired tag at the target locus.

Key Components

  1. Cas9 Protein: Creates a DSB at the target site.
  2. Guide RNA (gRNA): Directs Cas9 to the desired genomic locus.
  3. Donor Template: Contains the tag (e.g., GFP, HA tag) along with homology arms to facilitate HDR-mediated knock-in.

Feature of Our Products

  1. Our CRISPR and donor vectors are designed to be more streamlined, facilitating efficient target gene integration compared to commercially available products.
  2. Unlike market alternatives that require electroporation, which demand specialized equipment and techniques, our plasmid kits are user-friendly and suitable for most labs, making them ideal for adherent cancer cell lines. For hard-to-transfect cells, we also offer a hybrid solution that combines the large gene capacity of lentivirus with the reduced integration effects of AAV virus, providing a convenient, research-focused kit.

Experimental Process

  1. Design of gRNA and donor template vector:
    • The gRNA is designed to target a specific site, usually near the 3' or 5' end of the gene of interest to insert the tag without affecting the gene's function. The gRNA must be optimized to ensure high specificity and minimal off-target effects.
    • The donor template can be a plasmid or single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) and contains the tag flanked by homology arms (~500-1000 bp) that are homologous to the sequences surrounding the Cas9-induced DSB.
    • The tag can be fluorescent markers (e.g., GFP, mCherry), epitope tags (e.g., FLAG, HA), or functional domains (e.g., kinase domains, degradation signals).
  2. Cell Transfection, Screening and validation:
    • The Cas9/gRNA complex and the donor template are delivered into the cells via transfection (e.g., lipofection, electroporation, or viral delivery).
    • In hard-to-transfect cells, alternative delivery methods such as viral vectors (AAV or lentivirus) or RNP (ribonucleoprotein) complexes can be used to increase efficiency.
  3. Screening and Validation:
    • PCR-based screening is performed to confirm the successful integration of the tag into the target gene. Primers are designed to bind outside the homology arms and amplify across the knock-in site.
    • Sequencing is often performed to ensure correct and precise insertion without mutations.
    • If fluorescent tags are used, fluorescence microscopy or flow cytometry can be employed for preliminary screening.
    • After confirmation of the knock-in, Western blotting, immunofluorescence, or co-immunoprecipitation (Co-IP) may be used to validate the presence and functionality of the inserted tag.

Applications of CRISPR Gene Knock-In Tagging

This technique can be applied across a broad range of research areas, including investigating protein localization, studying protein-protein interactions, analyzing gene function and regulation, creating transgenic models, and facilitating drug discovery efforts.

fields.title: Gene Knock-Out
fields.content:
Technical Background

CRISPR knockout (KO) is a revolutionary gene-editing technique that allows researchers to disrupt or "knock out" specific genes within an organism's genome. The CRISPR-Cas9 system is the most widely used tool for this purpose, harnessing a natural bacterial defense mechanism against viral infections.

Key Components

  1. Cas9 Protein: An endonuclease that introduces double-strand breaks (DSBs) in the DNA at specific genomic locations.
  2. Guide RNA (gRNA): A short RNA sequence that directs the Cas9 protein to the target gene by complementary base pairing.
  3. Repair Pathways: Once the DSB is created, the cell's repair machinery activates. The primary pathways for repair are:
    • Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ): This repair mechanism often results in insertions or deletions (indels) at the break site, leading to frameshift mutations that can disrupt gene function.
    • Homology-Directed Repair (HDR): Less common for knockout purposes, HDR can be utilized when a donor template is provided, but is typically used for precise edits rather than knockouts.

By utilizing the NHEJ repair pathway, researchers can effectively create gene knockouts, leading to a loss of gene function.

Features of Our Products

  1. Our CRISPR and donor vectors are designed to be more streamlined, facilitating efficient target gene integration compared to commercially available products.
  2. Our product exhibits enhanced efficacy compared to the widely used lenti-V2 vector in the market, achieved through optimization of the gRNA structure and the provision of variable selection markers.

Experimental Process

  1. Design of gRNA:
    • The gRNA is designed to target a specific gene of interest, typically located in a conserved region of the gene to maximize the likelihood of knockout.
    • Various online tools can be used to design gRNA sequences with high specificity and minimal off-target effects.
  2. Delivery of Components:
    • The Cas9 protein and gRNA can be delivered into target cells using our kits, utilizing the corresponding transfection methods.
    • Plasmid Transfection: Introducing plasmid DNA encoding Cas9 and gRNA into cells.
    • Viral Vectors: Using lentiviruses or AAVs to deliver the editing components into hard-to-transfect cells.
  3. Screening and Validation:
    • PCR Screening: Amplifying the target region using specific primers to check for indel formation.
    • Functional Assays: Analyzing the impact of the knockout on cellular behavior, such as proliferation, apoptosis, or response to treatments.
    • Successful knockouts are validated through techniques such as Western blotting or immunofluorescence to confirm the absence of the target protein.
    • Further functional studies may be performed to assess the biological impact of the gene knockout.

Applications for CRISPR Gene Knock-In Tagging

This gene knockout (KO) product is ideal for genome-wide screening and gene function research, with applications in cancer studies, neuroscience, drug target discovery, and the engineering of immune cells for CAR-T cell therapy.

fields.title: CRISPR RNA Knock-down
fields.content:
Technical Background

CRISPR RNA Knockdown utilizing Cas13 is an innovative approach to post-transcriptional gene regulation. Unlike the Cas9 protein used in traditional CRISPR gene editing for introducing double-strand breaks, Cas13 is an RNA-guided RNA endonuclease that specifically targets and cleaves RNA molecules. This ability makes it an effective tool for knocking down gene expression by degrading messenger RNA (mRNA) transcripts.

Key Components:

  • Cas13 Protein: A member of the CRISPR family that targets RNA instead of DNA. Cas13 is derived from certain bacterial species, such as Leptotrichia shahii and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Guide RNA (gRNA): A synthetic RNA molecule designed to bind to the target mRNA. It contains a sequence complementary to the target RNA, directing Cas13 to the specific mRNA for cleavage.

Features of Our Products

  1. As an alternative to RNAi, our approach significantly reduces off-target activity in cultured cells compared to traditional RNA interference.
  2. We offer two distinct kits: vector kits designed for use with cancer cell lines and virus kits tailored for hard-to-transfect cells.

Experimental Process

Designing gRNA

  • gRNA is designed to specifically bind to the mRNA of the gene of interest. Tools are available to assist in selecting optimal gRNA sequences that minimize off-target effects.

Delivery of CRISPR Components

  • Plasmid Transfection: Introducing plasmid DNA encoding Cas13 and gRNA into cells.
  • Viral Vectors: Using lentiviruses or AAVs to deliver the components into hard-to-transfect cells.

Validation

  • Quantitative PCR (qPCR): Measuring the levels of the target mRNA to confirm successful knockdown.
  • Western Blotting: Assessing the corresponding protein levels to validate the reduction in gene expression.

Applications of CRISPR RNA Knockdown Using Cas13

Our techniques are expected to be used in various research areas including gene therapy, RNA regulatory studies, disease modeling, antiviral research, customized RNA-based therapies, and high-throughput genetic screening.

fields.title: Custom Cloning Services
fields.content:
Technology Background

  • Molecular Cloning Techniques: The service utilizes advanced molecular cloning methods such as restriction enzyme digestion, ligation, and Gibson assembly to construct vectors efficiently and accurately.
  • Promoter and Selection Marker Selection: Knowledge of various promoters and selection markers ensures that the constructed vectors provide robust expression in the intended host cells.
  • Viral Vector Engineering: For applications requiring stable gene expression, our service includes the design of viral vectors, such as lentiviruses and adeno-associated viruses (AAV), known for their ability to transduce a broad range of cell types.

Service Content

Design and Customization

  • Comprehensive design of expression vectors tailored to specific project needs, including promoter selection, gene insertion sites, and tag additions.
  • Customization options to include various elements such as reporters, selection markers, and regulatory sequences.

Vector Construction

  • Utilization of cutting-edge molecular cloning techniques to construct plasmids or viral vectors.
  • Options for standard plasmid construction, as well as complex designs for lentiviral and AAV vectors.

Validation and Quality Control

  • Rigorous validation of constructed vectors through sequencing to confirm the correct insertion and orientation of genes.
  • Functional assays to assess expression levels and activity of the target genes in appropriate cell models.

Delivery Systems

  • Consultation on the optimal delivery method for the constructed vector based on the target cell type, including standard transfection methods or viral transduction.

Technical Support

  • Ongoing technical support throughout the project, including assistance with transfection protocols and troubleshooting.

Application in Research

Vectors constructed through our service are suitable for various applications, including gene therapy, protein production, and functional studies of gene function and regulation.

fields.title: Lentivirus Package Services
fields.content:
Technology Background

Lentivirus Vectors Construction

The construction of lentiviral vectors commonly utilizes a three-plasmid system, which includes:

  • Transfer Plasmid: Contains the gene of interest and a promoter to drive expression.
  • Packaging Plasmid: Provides the necessary viral proteins (gag, pol, and rev) required for virus assembly.
  • Envelope Plasmid: Provides the envelope glycoprotein (e.g., VSV-G) that allows the virus to enter target cells.

Production Process

  • Transfection: The three plasmids are co-transfected into suitable producer cells (e.g., HEK293T cells) using a transfection reagent.
  • Virus Assembly and Release: The cells produce lentiviral particles, which are released into the culture medium.
  • Collection and Concentration: The lentiviral supernatant is harvested, filtered, and concentrated (if necessary) to yield a high-titer viral stock.

Service Content

Consultation and Project Design

  • Customization of lentiviral constructs to include specific genes, regulatory elements, or tags.

Lentivirus Packaging

  • Production of high-titer lentiviral stocks using optimized protocols to ensure maximum yield and purity.
  • Quality control assessments to confirm the titer, purity, and functionality of the lentivirus.

Transduction Services

  • Assistance with transducing target cell lines with the produced lentivirus, including optimization of transduction conditions.

Data and Reporting

  • Comprehensive reporting of lentivirus production, including titer determination, transduction efficiency, and any relevant quality control data.

Applications

This service product can be widely utilized in various research fields, including gene therapy, gene editing, high-throughput screening of gene functions, stable cell line generation, and the development of transgenic animal models.

fields.title: Stable Cell Line Services
fields.content:
Technology Background

Stable Cell Line Development

Stable cell lines are crucial for consistent and reproducible studies in gene function, drug discovery, and therapeutic research. The establishment of a stable cell line involves integrating a gene of interest into the host cell genome, allowing for continuous expression over many passages.

Vector Design

The choice of vector and the method of integration (random vs. targeted) play significant roles in the functionality and stability of the expressed protein. Our service focuses on minimizing random integration events, which can lead to silencing of the transgene or disruption of endogenous genes.

Transfection Methods

Different cell types necessitate various transfection techniques to achieve optimal expression. Currently, we offer two methods:

  • Standard Vectors: This approach offers lower integration rates and is ideal for delivering larger transgenes without disrupting host genes.
  • Lentiviral Transduction: This method allows for stable integration into the host genome, enabling the long-term expression of the gene of interest, even in non-dividing cells.

Selection and Validation

Employing selective markers ensures that only cells containing the desired genetic modifications are expanded. Subsequent validation techniques confirm successful integration and expression, providing assurance of experimental reliability.

Service Content

Customizable Cell Line Development

We offer tailored services to develop stable cell lines according to specific project requirements, including different cell types and functional characteristics.

Vector Construction

Design and construction of plasmid vectors containing the desired gene or genetic modification, often including selectable markers for efficient screening.

Transfection Techniques

  • Lipofection: For adherent cells.
  • Electroporation: For hard-to-transfect cell types.
  • Viral Transduction: Using lentiviruses or AAVs to deliver genetic material into target cells.

Selection and Expansion

  • Application of selective pressure (e.g., antibiotic selection) to isolate successfully transfected cells.
  • Expansion of selected clones in controlled environments.

Validation of Stable Cell Lines

  • Genomic Analysis: Verification of gene integration via PCR or sequencing.
  • Expression Analysis: Assessing the expression levels of the target gene using techniques such as qPCR, Western blotting, or flow cytometry.

Cryopreservation

Preservation of stable cell lines in liquid nitrogen for long-term storage and future use.

Technical Support

Ongoing consultation and support to help clients optimize their experiments using the generated cell lines.

Applications

The generated stable cell lines can be used for a wide range of applications, including drug screening, functional genomics, protein production, and mechanistic studies of disease.

fields.content:

fields.title: Overexpression Targeted Knock-In
fields.content:
Technical Background

Using CRISPR-Cas9 for targeted knock-in at safe harbor sites involves:

  • Cas9: An endonuclease that creates a double-strand break (DSB) at the target site.
  • Guide RNA (gRNA): Directs Cas9 to the specific safe harbor locus.
  • Donor DNA template: A construct containing the desired transgene flanked by homology arms that are complementary to the sequences adjacent to the DSB, which facilitates targeted insertion via homology-directed repair (HDR).

Safe harbor sites are specific regions in the genome where foreign DNA can be inserted without disrupting vital endogenous gene functions or causing harmful effects to the cell. These sites are often utilized for stable gene insertion in genome engineering because they support long-term and predictable expression of transgenes.

Several common safe harbor loci include:

  • AAVS1 (PPP1R12C locus) on chromosome 19
  • ROSA26 locus in mice
  • H11 locus in human and murine genomes

Features of Our Products

  1. Our CRISPR and donor vectors are designed to be more streamlined, facilitating efficient target gene integration compared to commercially available products.
  2. Many products rely on non-targeting lentivirus for gene incorporation, leading to random integration, which poses safety risks and unforeseen complications, particularly in gene therapy and clinical research. Our vector and virus kits, however, deliver targeted integration at specific safe harbor sites, significantly mitigating these risks.
  3. Unlike market alternatives that require electroporation, which demands specialized equipment and techniques, our plasmid kits are user-friendly and suitable for most labs, making them ideal for adherent cancer cell lines. For hard-to-transfect cells, we also offer a hybrid solution that combines the large gene capacity of lentivirus with the reduced integration effects of AAV virus, providing a convenient, research-focused kit.

Experiments Involved in CRISPR Targeted Knock-In at Safe Harbor Sites

Regular Plasmid

  • gRNA Selection: The guide RNA is designed to specifically target the chosen safe harbor site. The sequence must be carefully chosen to maximize on-target specificity and minimize off-target activity.
  • Cas9 Delivery: The CRISPR-Cas9 system can be delivered into cells using various methods such as plasmids, mRNA, or RNP (ribonucleoprotein complexes). Delivery methods depend on the cell type and the specific requirements of the experiment.
  • The donor DNA contains the gene of interest (GOI) along with homology arms (typically 500-1000 bp) that match the sequence flanking the target safe harbor site.
  • Depending on the application, the donor template may include selection markers (e.g., antibiotic resistance genes or fluorescent reporters) to aid in the identification of successfully modified cells.

Stable Cell Line Construction

  • Cell Type: Common cell types used include HEK293, iPSCs, and other therapeutic or industrially relevant cell lines.
  • Transfection: Cells are co-transfected with the gRNA, Cas9, and donor template using transfection methods such as electroporation, lipofection, or viral vectors (e.g., lentivirus or AAV). These methods vary depending on the cell type and efficiency requirements.
  • Antibiotic Selection/Fluorescence Screening: If the donor contains a selection marker, antibiotic resistance or fluorescence-based sorting (e.g., FACS) can be used to enrich cells that have undergone successful knock-in.
  • PCR and Sequencing: PCR is used to amplify the regions flanking the insertion site, followed by sequencing to confirm that the gene of interest was correctly integrated into the safe harbor locus.
  • Validation of Transgene Expression and Function

Applications of CRISPR Knock-In at Safe Harbor Sites

Our techniques are expected to be used in different research area including gene therapy, reporter or controlled gene applications, various disease models, antibody production, and iPSC regeneration.
